newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Mercenary says rebels have upper hand in Zaire.
newsitem.headline: Mercenary says rebels have upper hand in Zaire.

text.p: The Belgian who leads mercenaries fighting for the Zairian government said on Sunday that rebel forces currently held the upper hand.
Christian Tavernier also accused Uganda of supporting the rebels, fighting to overthrow Zaire's president of 31 years, Mobutu Sese Seko.
"There are well-organised armed units coming from Uganda who carry out an operation, attack a position, and then retreat," Christian Tavernier told Belgian radio RTBF.
"That means...the balance of strength is currently against us," he said on the telephone from eastern Zaire.
He added: "The Zairean army is in a tangle, like the rest of the country, with almost no logistics."
The rebels have advanced quickly from the east on several fronts, blunting an army counter-offensive launched from Zaire's third city of Kisangani on January 20.
Zaire defence ministry officials said on Sunday it was likely the eastern town of Kalima, about 400 km (250 miles) south of Kisangani, had been overrun by rebels.

Colonel Willy Mallants, a former adviser to President Mobutu who is now on the rebels' side, told RTBF that Kisangani was not a target as such. Mallants, who is now a political and military adviser for the Alliance of Democratic Forces of rebel leader Laurent Kabila, also accused the Zairean government of employing war criminals.

"Kisangani will not be a military target unless it is used as a base for criminal raids against civilians who have already suffered enough from aeroplanes commanded by Serbo-Croats and others from foreign countries who, if my information is correct, should be before the international tribunal in the Hague which must try war criminals," Mallants told RTBF in Brussels.
